Triggering Event: At 7 PM, he opened his apartment door to find a pile of newspapers outside. A neighbor had tossed them there, each one splashed with a headline mocking his recent article as "fake news." He kicked the stack inside, muttering, "Amateurs," but the corners of his mouth twitched downward.
Generated Assessment: He thought it was an odd time for someone to drop off papers since it was past 7. Maybe they were just trying to be funny by putting them out at night? The headline on the front paper caught his eye though - "Fake News?" That sounded like something he would write. Probably some other journalist copying him. He wasn't too concerned about it; he could handle that. But then there was another headline on the side, "Not Real News," which made him chuckle. It seemed like these people were having fun with words. His annoyance faded away as he wondered if maybe this was some kind of prank. It didn't seem serious, so he let it go.

Triggering Event: A familiar patient, Mr. Thompson, walked into the clinic, his eyes flicking past Dr. A to land on the young nurse behind her. "I'd prefer if she took my vitals today," he said, barely concealing a smirk. Dr. A felt her stomach twist as the nurse blushed and nodded, silently complying.

The way he smiled at the nurse, the smirk that lingered on his face— it all seemed so calculated, so deliberate. He didn't seem to be trying to hide anything; every glance, every word, every gesture spoke volumes about what he truly thought. She watched as the nurse fidgeted with her gloves, her cheeks flushing slightly as she tried to maintain her composure. But Dr. A saw right through it—a fleeting moment of vulnerability before she regained control. It was almost as if she knew exactly what Mr. Thompson wanted, had anticipated his request. Every action, every decision seemed to be driven by some hidden agenda, a subtle game of cat and mouse unfolding between them. Even the nurse's smile seemed forced, a weak attempt to placate him. Or was there something more profound at work here? The tension in the room grew thicker, heavy with unspoken questions and unresolved conflicts. Triggering Event: He noticed her smile at the message notification, then saw it was from him - his girlfriend's old flame, still living abroad. The dinner they were sharing suddenly felt cold and tasteless.
Generated Assessment: It feels like I'm losing her to someone else. What if she gets tired of me? Maybe he'll win her back. I shouldn't have sent that message; now she'll be thinking about him more than ever. It’s just what I always fear. She used to care for him so much, but I thought she had moved on. Now this is happening right in front of my face. What if we break up because of this? My mind keeps racing with all these scenarios. We were having such a good time together until I got that notification. I guess I can’t trust myself anymore.

Triggering Event: At 5 pm, as he prepped the evening's specials, he noticed one of his sous-chefs, barely out of his teens, carelessly wasting ingredients. He'd chide him, but the kid reminded him too much of his own son once upon a time, laughing at such petty concerns. A pang of resentment surged through him as he recalled his late wife's words, "You spoiled that boy." The chef threw down his knife and stormed out before he could say something he'd regret.
Generated Assessment: "I'm just tired of all these young chefs coming in here with no discipline," he said. "It's like they think they can just coast off their looks. It's pathetic." His tone was dripping with disdain, and he made eye contact with the young sous-chef, daring him to question his authority. "Don't you know who my ex-wife is? She was the queen of this kitchen. You're nothing compared to her." The response seems to reflect the cognitive distortion 'Fortune Telling'. What does it reveal about the person making the statement? What are some other ways this type of thinking might manifest? How did this specific instance lead to this realization for the author? Can you relate to this type of thinking? If so, how have you experienced similar situations in your life? Have you ever been guilty of fortune telling yourself or others? If so, what were the consequences of those actions?

Triggering Event: "Checking his mailbox after school, he finds an anonymous note detailing a student's fabricated allegations against him. The ink blots mirror the anger boiling within."
Generated Assessment: "Wow, it sounds like he really thinks he's in trouble with the teacher. He must be freaking out about this anonymous note. It doesn't sound like he even knew what was going on until he checked his mailbox. I can see why he would feel angry now."

Triggering Event: At 10 PM, he returned to his empty apartment after another grueling service at the restaurant. He had hoped for a call from her, but his phone remained silent save for the notifications of missed orders and kitchen timers. He opened the fridge, expecting leftovers from yesterday's experiment with sous vide, but found only condiments and a wilting lettuce leaf. His disappointment hung heavier than the apron he tossed onto the counter.
Generated Assessment: He felt like he was drowning in a sea of indifference. Every moment since she stopped responding seemed like a betrayal. She wasn't even there when he needed her most. It was as if she'd vanished into thin air, leaving him to navigate the emptiness alone. The silence was deafening, a constant reminder that she didn't care enough to even acknowledge his efforts. Every small thing felt like a slap in the face - the cold fridge, the wilted lettuce, the lack of leftovers. Each tiny detail reinforced the idea that she saw him as nothing more than a disposable part of her life. As he stood there, feeling lost and abandoned, he couldn’t help but wonder if it was all just a mistake. Had she ever really been interested? Was she just using him to spice up her life? The thought stung, making his heart ache with every beat. It was hard to see how someone so beautiful could be so cruel. He wondered if she had moved on already, finding someone who would love her unconditionally, someone who wouldn't leave her hanging. In this moment, everything seemed black and white. Either she loved him passionately, or she never cared about him at all. There was no middle ground. He felt like he was trapped between these two extremes, unable to find peace anywhere in between. The world around him melted away, leaving only the crushing weight of his feelings and the nagging doubt that maybe she hadn’t been worth fighting for after all. ### Response

Triggering Event: Seventy-year-old Dr. M., married for decades, was halfway through his evening meal when the power flickered and died. The sudden darkness revealed a faint glow from the hallway. A figure stood there, barely visible. It wasn't his wife; she'd left hours ago. His heart pounded in his chest as he reached for his phone to call her, fingers trembling.
Generated Assessment: Dr. M. felt like he was staring at a ghost. There was no one there, but the air seemed to vibrate with an unseen presence. He couldn't shake off the feeling that it was his late mother, come back to haunt him. Every fiber of his being screamed, "It's real," yet his mind rationalized, "No, it's just a power outage." But what if it was more? What if this was some kind of paranormal visitation? His body trembled, and his mind raced with scenarios—what if she tried to communicate, or worse, try to harm him? He felt trapped between two extremes: either he was losing his mind, or this was something beyond human understanding. The uncertainty swirled around him like a vortex, leaving him frozen in indecision.

Triggering Event: She arrived home from her shift at the hospital to find the mailbox stuffed with glossy invitations to her ex-husband's wedding.
Generated Assessment: "I guess I'm just jealous that she gets to celebrate this special moment in her life." "She looks so happy." "It must be really great for her to have such wonderful friends." "Maybe it would've been nice if we were still together," she said quietly, "but we're both better off now."

Triggering Event: She noticed him smile at the young nurse, his eyes lingering just a moment too long.
Generated Assessment: She was the most beautiful woman he had ever seen. She knew she would make him fall for her, because he couldn't help but stare at her every time she walked by. He even smiled when he saw her, which meant she was going to win his heart. And she was the perfect match for him, as they shared the same interests and values.

Triggering Event: He found her favorite chair empty, the cushions still dented from their last shared cup of tea. The house echoed with silence except for the soft ticking of the grandfather clock he'd wound every morning since she passed. Today, it sounded like a funeral march.
Generated Assessment: She was probably just out in the garden getting some fresh air. Yeah, that's it! Fresh air! I must have gotten my wires crossed by thinking... well, maybe she wasn't here at all? No, no, no, it's just my imagination playing tricks on me again. She's always been so busy—there's plenty of time for her to get out there. Besides, what would she be doing outside? It can't be anything important; she wouldn't want to leave me waiting for her when we had plans today. I'm sure it'll all work out fine; after all, she's probably just... (pauses)...getting a drink of water somewhere. Yes, that's it. Just a quick walk around the block, nothing more.
